node.title: Five cases of Omicron confirmed in ACT, 180 people linked to Lyneham Primary in quarantine
node.alt: A building with a red entrance and tree-lined path out front.
node.description: ACT Health have confirmed new cases of the Omicron variant of COVID-19 in Canberra, forcing 180 people from the Lyneham Primary School community into quarantine for 14 days.
node.content: ["There are now five cases of the Omicron variant of COVID-19 in the ACT, with one of the new cases forcing about 180 people linked to Lyneham Primary School into quarantine.", "Three more infections of the variant were confirmed yesterday \u2014 two are household contacts of the earlier cases and one is a casual contact \u2014 bringing the case total to five.", "ACT Health said\u00a0one of the cases had attended the inner north school on November 30 and December 1, sending 180 people into quarantine for 14 days, according to rules adjusted by ACT Health after the new variant was detected in the territory.", "In an email to parents, carers and staff of Lyneham Primary School, ACT Health said all year 1 and 2 students who were at school\u00a0on the two dates\u00a0have to quarantine.", "All students who attended before school care,\u00a0and\u00a0any\u00a0year 2-6 students who attended after school care,\u00a0on those dates, also have to quarantine.", "\"All household members of the close contact are also required to quarantine together with the close contact,\" the email said.", "\"Household members are not required to undergo COVID-19 testing unless they develop symptoms.\"", "Health Minster Rachel Stephen-Smith said this morning on ABC Radio Canberra\u00a0that vaccination status did not change whether a person had to quarantine for the full two weeks.", "She said it was quickly becoming clear the new variant was highly infectious and therefore required strict measures to control its spread.", "\"It's very early days, only very few cases, but we do seem to be seeing evidence that Omicron is actually very highly transmissible and places that were identified as casual contact sites have led to exposure \u2014\u00a0I think that was the first time that we've seen that in the ACT,\" she said.", "The school remains open to students and staff.", "More to come."]
